data.question: What is the purpose of carrying out single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiments at cryogenic temperatures?
data.answer: To obtain high-resolution data by reducing thermal disorder.

data.question: Why did the collection of diffraction data at lower temperature (100 K) not provide sufficient quality for MOF-1004 and MOF-1005?
data.answer: Disordered guest–framework interactions introduced disorder at low temperature.

data.question: True or False: The practice of collecting single-crystal X-ray diffraction data at cryogenic temperatures is always applicable to metal–organic frameworks (MOFs).
What was the initial data collection temperature for MOF-1005?
How does the presence of disordered guest molecules affect the framework of MOFs at low temperatures?
data.answer: It causes the framework to become more disordered due to stronger interactions.

data.question: True or False: The inverse behavior of disorder increasing at lower temperatures was observed for MOF-177 and UiO-67.
What method was used for the activation of MOF-1004?
What effect does the temperature swing procedure have on the organization of guest molecules in UiO-66?
data.answer: It makes the disordered guests in the pores more ordered.

data.question: True or False: The removal of guest molecules by heating to 400 K and subsequent cooling to 100 K did not affect the ⟨I/σ⟩ value of UiO-66.
What was the effect of guest removal on the atomic displacement parameters (ADPs) of UiO-66?
data.answer: ADPs were significantly reduced, indicating less disorder.

data.question: True or False: The presence of disordered guest molecules in the pores of MOFs always enhances the X-ray scattering power.
What is the space group of MOF-1004?
How does the presence of defects affect the disorder in UiO-67 crystals?
data.answer: Crystals with more defects showed less pronounced reduction of disorder upon cooling.

data.question: True or False: The disordered guest–framework interactions are less pronounced in MOFs with lower porosity.
What was the main conclusion regarding the collection of data on crystals of MOFs?
data.answer: Disordered guest–framework interactions play a profound role in introducing disorder at low temperatures.

data.question: True or False: The study found that the practice of collecting X-ray diffraction data at cryogenic temperatures is beneficial for all types of crystals.
What was the effect of increasing temperature on the resolution of diffraction data for MOF-1004?
data.answer: High temperatures reduced the disorder and gave high-resolution diffraction data.

data.question: True or False: UiO-66 exhibited the inverse behavior of increased disorder at lower temperatures.
What was the method used for solvent exchange in MOF-1005?
How did the temperature swing procedure affect the electron density maps in UiO-66?
data.answer: More localized densities were observed after the temperature swing.
